Author: Alright#0419
Content: they want to embed what data?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```
Thanks for this PR.

When the format for Sapling incoming viewing keys (section 5.6.6 of the protocol spec) was defined, I overlooked that there would not be sufficient information to tell which address it was meant for. We'll need to consider whether the external format should change in order to include that information, before merging this PR or equivalent.
```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/zcash/zcash/pull/3822

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Ahhh yes, that would be good to have

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it's not a hard fork or anything, is it?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: no

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this is RPC level stuff

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's like a new kind of private key, which is only for sapling zaddrs and only gives you "watchonly" access to incoming xtns

Author: Alright#0419
Content: new format can be <view key><z addr> üòÇ

Author: Alright#0419
Content: why does it need to be "embedded"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alright can't tell which level of irony or trolling you are on üòÖ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alright what you describe is very similar, just very wasteful of space

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: bech32 representation of something takes more bytes than storing a pubkey as a 64bit int in a special way, then doing one base58/bech32 of the whole thing

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c anywhere you want to use an IVK, you will need to store zaddr+IVK, does that work for your needs?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are worried about space when the current state is not having any way of doing it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will be used in atomic swaps, which will need to include chain, zaddr, etc

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c and you plan to store all that in the memo field, yes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each use case would need to simply store it, like if  a wallet uses it, it should put it in the wallet

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: there is plenty of room there, it's unused space in most transactions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: makes sense to keep everything in the memo, including ordermatch details

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i thought something was horribly broken and that is why it wasnt merged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this just means that it requires the caller to track some extra data. seems one of the sillier reasons to not have what is basically a critically needed functionality

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with this, you can also prove you sent payments

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Last official word: `We'll need to consider whether the external format should change in order to include that information, before merging this PR or equivalent.`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so Zcash needs to consider whether the format *should* change

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: They didn't give the author of the PR any direction at all

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that was 2 months ago, the PR just gets more stale

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we should thank the author for a perfectly usable viewing kyes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: This is pretty standard zec behavior. They often let my trivial commits sit for months while they decide about minutiae

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/zcash/zcash/pull/3822#issuecomment-486216118

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I thanked the author

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c worst case is that ZEC comes out with an amazing new IVK format, and we upgrade to that. I agree with you, let's use this, it's very nice

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i remember seeing something about being able to efficiently detect incoming amounts to a large number of different addresses

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: do you know about that?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c maybe, describe it a bit more?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: currently if your wallet has 10,000 addresses, it is very slow to detect incoming amounts

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: "diversified addresses" are a thing, I don't know if those have been merged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, what is it?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes, "diversified addresses"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: let me make sure I use the correct terminology

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c basically, it's BIP32 for sapling, called ZIP32: https://github.com/zcash/zips/blob/master/zip-0032.rst

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c https://github.com/zcash/zcash/pull/3492

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's recently merged, but I don't think it's being fully utilized

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the TLDR is this: It means you can give out a unique shielded address, that can't be linked to any other zaddr

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but has the same private key as your "main zaddr"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I think. Please correct me if I am wrong.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is more efficient to see if funds came in from a bunch of addresses?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont see it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is just bip32, you would still need to check all the different addresses

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Many diversified addresses can map to one IVK, is one thing

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so that means you import one IVK but listen to N diversified addresses

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I don't know about performance implications

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and docs about this stuff is almost non-existent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, then you can tell a deposit came into one of the addresses, but then wouldnt it be needed to scan all addresses, or there is some extra data in the ivk that shows which diversified address? i guess we need to wait for docs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c that is what I was talking about, if you don't know which diversified address, you have to do a full scan. There are no docs, in the spec or code, currently

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1121045671715454976

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: spreading the good word

Author: scubapanda#2485
Content: @dukeleto Sorry if this is a trivial question but I didn't get the point of incoming viewing key keeping track of the address it's related to. How would one do this? Wouldn't this only be useful if you have the private/spending key in the wallet already? To find out which addresses the viewing key is good for, without the private key already in the wallet, you'll always have to scan the chain to see which transactions it matches? If the private key, matching this viewing key, is already there, can't you then just check which one of these existing private keys it 'matches' - if any.

Content: ehr ma gherd, this will make my life sooo much easier

Content: @scubapanda not sure you understand. This is like "watchonly" addresses for shielded addresses

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢ finalized transactions, oh the joy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alright that means "set nSequence to the largest value allowed to be stored in a uint32_t"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I didn't know about "finalized" until recently, it's really low level stuff, below the level of confirmations

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢ non-finalized means the transaction does not meet the requirements for timestamps and median blocktimes and it all gets very hairy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's not a bug in your code, sounds like funky timestamps that were by accident or perhaps somebody playing with timewarp attacks

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `IsFinalTx()` in src/main.cpp has a printf you can uncomment to get more debug data
